title: What are some important applications of game theory? - Quora

response.answer_text: Historically, game theory started with the analysis of two-player, zero-sum games. (These are games where one player’s gain is equivalent to another player’s loss.) The first major work in the field (Theory of Games and Economic Behavior) was published in 1944, and that same year Allied forces used the principles of game theory to construct a search pattern for German submarines in the Straits of Malacca. This, I suspect, is the first direct “application” of game theory. It should be noted, of course, that some economic models which predate “game theory” feel very much like game theory. I am thinking in particular of Cournot competition, an important economic insight that dates to 1838. In 1950, the famous Prisoner's dilemma was “invented;” this was influential at the time because it showed that while Adam Smith’s “Invisible hand” may apply to competitive markets, (see Fundamental theorems of welfare economics), in other situations individuals acting in their self interest may not lead to socially optimal outcomes. As others have mentioned, game theory would go on to revolutionize political science and economics. (I’m not sure whether evolutionary game theory has “revolutionized” biology, but it is definitely a notable subfield.) It has direct applications in multiagent systems in computer science, but there are also computer scientists who are interested in studying how the theory of algorithms applies to games. If I think of anything that’s been missed, I’ll edit this answer.

Evolutionary game theory provides an analytic basis for explaining the emergence of subtle behaviors in animals over an evolutionary timescale.Evolutionary game theory (EGT) is the application of game theory to evolving populations in biology. It defines a framework of contests, strategies, and analytics into which Darwinian competition can be modeled. Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviors in Darwinian evolution. It has in turn become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers. 2) In network designs, there is the issue of fairness as network clients compete for access to resources.
